abstract.p: Craig J Cantoni letter on Walter Goodman's April 19 article on television's 'talking heads'; takes exception to his characterization of George Will as 'right winger'; contends Will is simply a conservative intellectual who wears a bow tie

block.p: In Walter Goodman's article ''They Let the Talking Heads Talk, but They Set the Tone'' [April 19], he states that the commentator George Will turns ''in the blink of a commercial'' into ''the committed (or commitable) right winger.''

In Walter Goodman's article ''They Let the Talking Heads Talk, but They Set the Tone'' [April 19], he states that the commentator George Will turns ''in the blink of a commercial'' into ''the committed (or commitable) right winger.''

Right winger? Gee, I thought that he was simply a conservative intellectual, with strong libertarian leanings, who believes in small government, personal responsibility, individual rights instead of group rights, a strict interpretation of the United States Constitution, and legislations through democratically elected legislatures instead of appointed judges or unelected bureaucrats. Mr. Goodman made it sound as if Mr. Will wore army fatigues and camouflage paint instead of a bow tie.
